COMM: Igor Vovkovinsky lives in Rochester,

82.11.text:
Minnesota. 27 year-old Igor suffers from Acromegalic
Gigantism and at 7ft 8’ he towers over his

94.34.text:
01:34
Igor: You making coffee for breakfast?

97.15.text:
01:39
COMM: Symptoms of gigantism include rapid

102.55.text:
01:44
Igor: Being tall makes the world very annoying.

107.52.text:
Every structure that I go into is too small,
too short. I end up hitting my head on all

113.35.text:
the exit signs. The world is just a very uncomfortable
place for someone my size.

119.57.text:
02:01
COMM: Igor was born in the Ukraine and his

123.45.text: size became a problem from a very early age.

126.14.text:
02:07
SVETLANA: When Igor was born he was growing

129.16.text:
too fast. At the age 4,5,6 months he already
was size of 1 year old kid. Usually when kids

137.33.text:
are born and if they are big size born, in
my home country actually people are happy.

143.88.text:
But when he was 6 months old and weighed 13
kilos I thought it was a little too heavy.

149.11.text:
A little too big. I went to see the doctors
and it was the first time he say to me it

155.64.text: has Gigantism, when he was six months old.

159.68.text:
02:41
COMM: Gigantism is caused by a tumour on the

163.83.text:
pituitary gland inside the brain. This tumour
produces an excess of growth hormone which

169.41.text:
is pumped into the body. If a person suffers
the brain tumour before the end of puberty

175.01.text:
then the condition is called acromegalic gigantism
and results in the patient growing to massive

180.26.text:
heights, like Igor. But if a person develops
the tumour post puberty then the condition

185.81.text:
is called acromegaly and the patient grows
outwards rather than upwards. Acromegaly affects

192.26.text:
three to four out of every million people
each year.

195.30.text:
03:16
DR JAKOBY: What most individuals notice right

198.35.text:
away is that there’s a characteristic facial
appearance of individuals with Acromegaly.

204.21.text:
The frontal bones become broadened and enlarged
and more prominent. The nose enlarges. The

211.14.text:
facial features and skin coarsen. The jaw
becomes more prominent. Another striking feature

216.76.text:
of Acromegaly is the significant enlargement
of the hands and feet and you read descriptions

222.14.text:
of patients with Acromegaly have spade like
hands and spade like feet. The fingers and

227.53.text:
toes thicken and the palms and soles widen
and get thickened as well.

231.78.text:
03:52
COMM: Both acromegaly and acromegalic gigantism

235.58.text:
can result in severe disfigurement, serious
disorders such as heart problems and strokes,

244.44.text:
04:06
COMM: Doctors in the Ukraine were unable to

248.22.text:
perform a much needed operation to remove
Igor’s brain tumour, meaning he continued

253.13.text:
to grow. So, when he was seven, and already
standing six feet tall, Igor and his mum moved

259.01.text:
to America, where doctors were able to carry
out the operation.

262.65.text:
04:25
SVETLANA: The surgery saved his life but he

267.77.text:
still was growing after surgery for many more
years. None of us expected that. I always

273.47.text:
thought that after surgery he would stop growing
but his brain was already affected by tumour

280.84.text: and still was producing growth hormone.

284.15.text:
04:46
COMM: Igor eventually stopped growing when

288.93.text:
he was 20 years old.
But not until he’d hit an amazing 7ft 8’

296.21.text:
– making him one the tallest men in the
world.

300.01.text:
05:02
IGOR: Gigantism has affected me that I feel

305.05.text:
that I no longer feel that l fit into any
part of society and that’s a feeling that

311.58.text:
I’ve had ever since I went to middle school
and high school.

315.29.text:
05:16
COMM: Igor has recently enrolled at college

318.38.text:
to continue his education, which has been
badly interrupted by his condition.

326.92.text:
05:41
COMM: He’s studying to become a lawyer and

346.12.text:
05:50
IGOR: I’m used to always sitting in the

352.27.text:
small chairs and sitting at the small tables
and it’s uncomfortable but I don’t want

357.93.text:
to make an extra fuss about it so I’m used
to bending over and sitting in the little

364.93.text: chairs and writing at the little desks.

367.46.text:
06:08
COMM: Igor’s school life has not always

371.72.text:
06:12
IGOR: High School was a terrible experience.

375.57.text:
All four years of high school were just incredibly
harsh. I never had anybody to talk to during

382.56.text:
school or after school. I never sat with anybody
at lunch. High school was just four miserable

389.48.text:
years because I was just standing out of the
crowd and didn’t fit into any group, any

394.71.text:
social group and it felt like I was a nuisance
to everybody in school.

398.89.text:
06:39
COMM: Despite his difficult experience during

401.59.text:
high school, the medical help Igor has received
drives his desire to be a lawyer.

406.13.text:
06:46
IGOR: A lot of people have helped us over

409.30.text:
these years that we’ve lived here and I
feel that more people should have the opportunity

414.67.text: to receive the help that I did.

416.59.text:
06:56
COMM: Although his height means he struggles

418.76.text:
to be accepted in his everyday life, as we’ll
see Igor does make a big impression at the

425.35.text:

I just want to make some special acknowledgments.

The biggest Obama fan in the country is in

normal kids stuff and I had a ball. I remember

503.33.text:

half stone. Now aged 31, she’s 6ft 8 and

980.71.text:
is the tallest man in history. And Wadlow
was still growing when he died because of

991.66.text: his condition at the age of just 22.

996.25.text:
16:41

1003.99.text:
suffers from Acromegalic gigantism and measures

his height Igor’s house has had to be specially
made to accommodate him.

1015.76.text:
16:58

1019.91.text:
for me. We had to special order all the doors.

of our doors are 8 feet high so I don’t

of the house is custom too. We have cathedral

17:17

17:23

I just want to make some special acknowledgments.

1121.30.text:

IGOR: So that was all great.

age of 7 Igor finally stopped growing when

Igor’s life, gigantism continues to affect

1141.34.text:
putting pressure on his limbs, joints and

19:19

for a reason so I don’t think I want to

1536.03.text:

Mary was recently diagnosed with Acromegaly.

1542.66.text:
25:44

1547.12.text:
She has pretty much all the issues. She has
the changes in physical appearance. The problems

1555.65.text:
25:57
COMM: Mary suffers from the same condition

1558.83.text:
as Igor and Tanya. But because she became
ill after she’d been through puberty, meaning

1564.09.text:
her growth plates were closed, Mary’s growth
is different. Instead of growing very tall,

1570.63.text:
she has founds that her face, hands and feet

1574.27.text:

MARY: My jaw line is growing, my teeth have

1578.64.text:
are separating, my lip, my bottom lip is growing,

27:56

1678.87.text: she hopes will be life changing surgery.

1686.49.text:
28:17
COMM: Since being diagnosed with acromegaly

1699.51.text:
9 years ago Tanya Angus’ life has turned
upside down. Today Tanya’s travelled into

1714.58.text:
Las Vegas to pick up something that most people
take for granted…a pair of shoes.

1725.12.text:
28:47
COMM: Before she became ill Tanya wore a size

1729.55.text:
8 shoe. But because she’s grown so much
she now wears a size 15 and it’s impossible

1735.64.text: for her to find women’s shoes that fit.

1737.71.text:
28:58
COMM: As a result she has to wear a pair of

1740.57.text:
men’s sandals…and even they’re incredibly
uncomfortable for her. These shoes have been

1746.12.text:
specially designed and made for Tanya by a
local shoemaker.

1749.39.text:
29:10
TANYA: I love them. I want to go out. I want

1754.28.text:
29:16
COMM: Whilst for most people buying shoes

1757.91.text:
is a simple day to day exercise, Tanya’s
new pair means so much.

1762.68.text:
29:23
TANYA: I love having the shoes. It’s almost

1770.72.text:
29:32
COMM: And this is just another small boost

1773.78.text:
that will make a massive difference to her
quality of life.

1776.60.text:
29:38
TANYA: It feels unbelievable it really does.

1781.23.text:
It’s something I would have never would
have imagined. I though that was a part of

1788.11.text:
my past.
KAREN: I’m so happy

1789.95.text:
29:59
COMM: Later that day Tanya and her mum are

1800.94.text:
preparing to spend the afternoon being pampered
as they have their nails done. And for Tanya,

1808.25.text:
it’s important to do things that a normal
31 year-old woman would do.

1812.55.text:
30:15
TANYA: It’s important because it makes me

1816.06.text:
forget about my tumour and it’s no good
sitting around the house just thinking about

1827.93.text:
30:33
COMM: Because of her size, for Tanya something

1836.19.text:
as simple as a manicure / pedicure is an uncommon
occurrence.

1839.64.text:
30:42
TANYA: Oh my gosh, wow…yeah it feels good,

1850.55.text:
wow. I feel special right now.
KAREN: Oh, look how pretty, very pretty.

1862.14.text: TANYA: You like them? I do.

1868.52.text:
31:10
COMM: The kind of attention that Tanya has

1872.10.text:
received today helps her forget about her
medical problems, at least for a while.

1877.18.text:
31:17
TANYA: The size part you never can drop, even

1881.52.text:
when you’re having a good day but it takes
the medical part away, you know, I’m not

1888.18.text:
seeing any doctors today, I’m not dealing
with the injections or anything else you know,

1895.65.text: it’s just a laugh and have fun day.

1899.30.text:
31:42
COMM: Forgetting all about her medical problems

1903.88.text:
is great news but in two days time Tanya will
be visiting her doctor where she’s hoping

1909.27.text:
for even better news about the fight against
her continuing growth.

1913.26.text: KAREN: This disease could kill Tanya.

1920.96.text:
32:11
COMM: Atlanta, Georgia is home to one of America’s

1934.20.text:
most prestigious hospitals. The Emory Clinic.
Mary White has recently discovered that she

1944.61.text:
has acromegaly. A condition caused by a tumour
on the pituitary gland inside her brain.

1951.30.text:
Those words, brain tumour would just drop
your jaw, that automatically you think your

1965.84.text:
32:48
COMM: Whilst not cancerous, this tumour produces

1970.40.text:
an excess of growth hormone, that means parts
of Mary’s body, such as her lips, skull

1975.71.text:
and hands have started to grow.
Men and women are equally likely to be affected

1981.19.text:
by acromegaly and the average age of diagnosis
is 42.

1986.50.text:
32:10
MARY: I have not felt normal in my life in

1992.99.text:
33:14
COMM: Having recently been diagnosed at the

1995.48.text:
age of 52, Mary is a good example of how acromegaly
can affect anyone, at any time.

2001.08.text:
33:22
DR OYESIKU: To the best of our knowledge nobody’s

2003.64.text:
protected from developing acromegaly. The
majority of patients develop it sporadically,

2009.30.text:
in other words they literally just wake up
and they have the condition.

2013.71.text:
33:34
COMM: Now she’s scheduled to undergo surgery,

2016.76.text:
that will hopefully stop her body’s growth
and change her life forever.

2020.02.text:
33:41
MARY: For me personally I hope that it gives

2024.47.text:
me some sort of normalcy to my life. The peace
of mind of knowing that the years that would

2031.43.text:
have been taken away from me have been given
back.

2034.48.text:
33:55
COMM: Dr. Nelson Oyesiku has performed over

2038.50.text:
1400 operations on Pituitary tumours. But
still there are risks with any operation inside

2045.37.text:
34:07
DR OYESIKU: The risks of surgery in this type

2048.14.text:
of operation include the risk of infection
and on either side of the pituitary gland

2052.51.text:
lies on artery called the carotid artery,
it supplies your brain with blood and if you

2057.08.text:
put your finger on your neck you can feel
the pulse of the carotid artery. And the surgeon

2061.32.text:
operating in this area has to be exceedingly
careful to make sure he doesn’t perturb

2066.02.text:
the carotid artery because of the risk of
bleeding or the risk of stroke.

2071.07.text:
34:31
COMM: The carotid artery supplies the brain

2073.43.text:
with blood. Disrupting this artery could have
catastrophic consequences.

2079.30.text:
34:54
COMM: Later that evening, Mary is spending

2085.82.text:
her last night before the operation with her
husband Ed.

2090.10.text:
Having heard how delicate the procedure is,
she’s fully aware of the risks.

2093.86.text:
34:56
MARY: I still worry about the things that

2099.73.text:
could go wrong, any time you’re inside somebody’s
head and messing about with their brain things

2106.56.text:
could go wrong so it’s only natural to worry
about that. But I’m not going to let it

2112.19.text:
stop me from doing what I know I’ve got
to do.

2114.81.text:
35:17
COMM: In a few short hours Mary will undergo

2119.77.text:
the operation that she and Ed hope will mark
the beginning of a new life.

2127.31.text:
35:36
COMM: It’s the morning of Mary’s operation.

2138.65.text:
The time has finally come for the tumour to
be removed from her brain.

2142.09.text:
35:43
ED: This is very important, I want to be with

2145.39.text:
her forever and with this disease there’s
a possibility that she wouldn’t have but

2152.56.text:
a few more years, you know, maybe six and
I want our life together to be longer than

2159.45.text:
36:00
COMM: Doctors will remove Mary’s tumour

2161.75.text:
through her nose, using a technique called
Endonasal Transphenoidal neurosurgery. Her

2169.18.text:
operation will be carried out by a team of
surgeons led by Dr Nelson Oyeskiku, who is

2176.85.text:
What we do is we go through the nasal passages
into the sphenoid sinus which leads you to

2182.34.text:
the back of the pituitary gland. And we do
that using an instrument called an endoscope

2188.23.text:
and an endoscope is a tube that about that
long and has light going through it and a

2194.94.text:
lens that obviously allows you to see the
field that you’re working in.

2201.16.text:
36:43
COMM: As Mary’s wheeled into surgery her

2206.39.text:
36:47
MARY: The thought of having the operation

2208.76.text:
scares me, it always has. If I said it didn’t
I’d be lying. You try to put on a brave

2214.57.text:
front but you can’t not visualise or think
about somebody going up inside your head and

2222.63.text: removing something and not be afraid.

2225.37.text:
37:08
COMM: Mary’s head has to be clamped in place

2230.79.text:
because there’s no room for error. As well
as avoiding damage to the carotid artery the

2236.31.text:
surgeons also have to be very careful with
Mary’s optic nerve which is situated just

2241.50.text:
millimetres from the pituitary gland and damaging
it could leave Mary with impaired sight. Despite

2248.24.text:
these risks, Mary is hopeful that the surgery
will reverse many of her symptoms.

2252.87.text:
37:34
MARY: I know I have changed so much, I fought

2258.42.text:
it for so long but I know I’m not the same
person. But I have hope that I will be.

2265.14.text:
37:47
DR OYESIKU: Most of the soft tissue changes

2271.05.text:
we see in patients, once they go into remission
and they stay in remission, you can actually

2277.22.text:
see those reverse. The things that we have
the most problems with reversing are things

2283.89.text:
like bony structure because those are hard
and fast if you will.

2290.89.text:
38:16
COMM: Two hours in and the doctors have located

2298.87.text:
the tumour. It’s now a matter of cutting
the growth away without leaving any damage

2303.94.text: – one slip could cause catastrophic results.

2308.42.text:
38:29
DR OYESIKU: Cotton ball please. Second specimen.

2322.80.text:
38:45
COMM: Finally the tumour is removed. With

2331.68.text:
Doctor Oyesiku taking extra care to avoid
the Carotid artery and optic nerve.

2336.32.text:
38:58
DR OYESIKU: That’s a growth hormone, see

2341.15.text:
39:03
COMM: The tumour measures about a centimetre

2344.19.text:
across. Ironic that something so small can
loom so large in someone’s life.

2351.28.text:
39:13
COMM: After three hours the procedure is over

2355.33.text:
and the operation has gone well. But it will
be 12 weeks before doctors can carry out tests

2361.08.text:
that will prove conclusively whether they’ve
brought Mary’s growth hormone levels under

2366.35.text:
39:37
DR OYESIKU: Hi there Miss White.

2375.36.text:
39:39
COMM: It’s the day after the operation and

2381.24.text:
Mary is awake, if a little groggy. Dr. Oyesiku
is visiting her to explain how the operation

2387.79.text:
39:51
DR OYESIKU: Everything went just as planned,

2391.50.text:
we didn’t have any problems what so ever.
We found the tumour just like we predicted

2396.81.text:
and we didn’t run into any problems with
the carotid artery or any bleeding so hopefully

2401.37.text: just a couple of days in the hospital.

2403.41.text:
40:05
COMM: While the procedure went well, conclusive

2407.38.text:
proof of success will be available with the
results from Mary’s growth hormone test

2412.58.text:
40:13
DR OYESIKU: If those are good then there’s

2414.15.text:
a very good chance that you’ll stay cured
for the long haul.

2418.09.text:
40:21
MARY: My whole family, my children, my grandchildren,

2422.83.text:
my husband they want their momma back, they
want their Mary back. They want the same person

2430.77.text:
on the outside that they know is on the inside,
they haven’t had that in a while.

2435.07.text:
40:35
COMM: And for now the future is already looking

2437.50.text:
brighter for Mary, as Dr. Oyesiku is confident
that the reversal of her physical changes

2443.99.text:
40:44
DR OYESIKU: You will notice your features

will get softer. Actually I can also see already
that they’re getting softer. It’s hard

2450.13.text:
to tell for someone who’s not used to seeing
it but once you’ve seen the changes in acromegaly

2456.25.text:
it’s not too difficult to even discern very
subtle changes at a very early stage.

2462.66.text:
41:03
MARY: I have nothing to do but smile and look

2466.28.text:
forward to the future, I know things are going
to be better, I know they are.

2473.04.text:
41:14
COMM: The early signs are that Mary’s operation

2477.11.text:
has been a success and she should reap the
benefits.

2485.05.text:
41:34
COMM: Nine years ago Tanya Angus underwent

2497.30.text:
exactly the same operation that Mary has just
had. But unfortunately doctors were unable

2502.69.text:
to remove all of her tumour, meaning she continues
to grow. Tonight, Tanya’s putting her medical

2508.68.text:
worries behind her, and hitting the highlight
of her home town – the casino! This is a

2519.31.text:
chance for Tanya to get away from everything
and just have a good time with her sister

2523.46.text:
and her mum – who plays a huge role in her
life.

2526.86.text:
42:08
TANYA: She’s my rock. If I hit the million

2532.82.text: dollar thing, I would share it with my mum

2538.25.text:
42:20
COMM: Since being diagnosed aged 22 Tanya

2542.17.text:
has grown over a foot and gained more than
21 stone. But her weight gain has nothing

2547.52.text: to do with her eating habits.

2548.88.text:
42:30
TANYA: I have a very small appetite. I never

2552.84.text:
feel like eating. I mean my mom and my sister
have to remind me. Did you eat today?

2559.02.text:
42:40
COMM: It’s Tanya’s growth hormone that’s

2561.98.text:
responsible for her increased weight and tomorrow

2566.63.text: of her latest growth hormone test.

2568.43.text:
42:49
KAREN: If we could get her growth hormone

2571.64.text:
level to be under a thousand her growth would

2581.88.text:
adjust and not hopefully be as difficult and
a challenge.

2592.71.text:
43:14
COMM: Later that evening, Tanya is preparing

2595.88.text:
to go to bed. One of the symptoms of acromegaly
is sleep apnoea because patients’ tongues

2602.99.text:
often grow so large they block their airways,
which stops them from breathing. As a result

2608.52.text:
Tanya has to sleep with a machine called a
C-Pap to help her breath at night. As she

2616.34.text:
goes to sleep she’s hoping that the morning
brings some much needed good news.

2623.54.text:
43:49
COMM: The following day Tanya’s travelled

2630.68.text:
to meet Dr. Michael Jackoby to discover if

2636.74.text: there’s a lot resting on the consultation.

2639.22.text:
44:00
KAREN: This disease could kill Tanya.

2646.42.text:
44:10

2652.91.text:
level drops, as they’ve been informed that
this would slow her growth considerably and

2659.98.text:
We’re praying that it goes lower. If it
goes higher...it will be very bad news.

2669.00.text:

2684.83.text:

really happy for you and hopefully that will

KAREN: That’s the best ever. April 25th

2002 it’s never been that low. So that new

2719.17.text:
45:23
DR JAKOBY: Yeas its working quite well. I

was really happy to see how well you responded.
And the nice thing is I think we have more

2729.23.text:
45:31
COMM: With the new drug regime seemingly offering

2732.99.text:
hope, Tanya’s future is now more positive

2736.47.text:
45:37
KAREN: This is like the best Christmas present

2740.78.text:
we could ever have, because this is the first
time since Tanya’s been diagnosed that it

2747.81.text:
has been under 1000 and that means that they
are gaining control. And we’ve never had

2756.65.text:
45:58

2759.94.text:
now that her growth hormone has been reduced,
Tanya’s growth should decrease. And while

2765.40.text:
she’ll have to take the drugs for the rest
of her life her doctors feel that there’s

2771.20.text:
46:12
Tanya: It’s so unbelievable. It’s great.

2776.86.text:
It makes me feel like I have a brand new lease
on life. I’m going to take those shots regularly.

2785.87.text:
Heck if I have to I’ll take them twice a

2792.59.text:
46:36
COMM: Like Tanya, Mary recently received good

2798.57.text:
news. Twelve weeks after her surgery she returned
to Atlanta for tests. She has now been given

2808.08.text:
46:52
COMM: Igor continues to follow his dream of

2814.62.text:
becoming a lawyer. Although his growth is

2820.40.text:
day and is still learning to live with the

2828.40.text:
47:10

2832.51.text:
cases of acromegaly that doctors have ever

2838.04.text: hope in her battle against this terrible condition.

2841.61.text:
47:22

because a friend of mine told me, anything
